citation.article-title: Desulfosalsimonas propionicica gen. nov., sp. nov., a halophilic, sulfate-reducing member of the family Desulfobacteraceae isolated from a salt-lake sediment
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Desulfosalsimonas propionicica sp. nov.

Desulfosalsimonas propionicica (pro.pi.o.ni.ci′ca. N.L. n. acidum propionicum propionic acid; L. fem. suff. -ica suffix used with the sense of pertaining to; N.L. fem. adj. propionicica belonging to propionic acid).
The species has the following characteristics in addition to those listed for the genus.
Cells are 0.8–1.0 μm wide and 2–4 μm long, sometimes forming filaments.
Utilizes (with sulfate as electron acceptor) propionate, pyruvate, lactate, butyrate, isobutyrate, fumarate, ethanol, 1-propanol, 1-butanol, yeast extract and H2/acetate.
Oxidizes lactate and propionate completely and ethanol and propanol incompletely.
Yeast extract is required for growth.
In addition to sulfate, thiosulfate and sulfite serve as electron acceptors.
NaCl is required for growth and up to 200 g NaCl l−1 is tolerated; the optimum concentration for growth is 60 g l−1.
Growth occurs within the range pH 6.0–8.3.
Growth occurs at 15–40 °C (optimum about 40 °C); growth is absent at 10 and 45 °C.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 54.1 mol%.
The type strain, PropAT (=DSM 17721T =VKM B-2385T), was isolated from the extreme hypersaline sediment of the northern arm of Great Salt Lake, Utah, USA.
